title: acropalypse screenshot recovery utility

last_post.content:
CVE-2023-21036 / acropalypse is absolutely bonkers.

Apparently for 5+ years the cropping / editing tools for screenshots on Google Pixel phones was only overwriting the start of the screenshot PNG file, but not truncating.

All screenshots shared for the past 5+ years might have data recoverable from them. Demo available at https://acropalypse.app/

Google still hasn't communicated anything on this.

(h/t ItsSimonTime on Musk's site)

title: Copyright and Artificial Intelligence | U.S. Copyright Office

last_post.content: The Copyright Office has launched an initiative to examine the copyright law and policy issues raised by artificial intelligence (AI) technology, including the scope of copyright in works generated using AI tools and the use of copyrighted materials in AI training. After convening public listening sessions in the first half of 2023 to gather information about current technologies and their impact, the Office will publish a notice of inquiry in the Federal Register. https://copyright.gov/ai/?loclr=eanco

title: The Internet Archive has lost its first fight to scan and lend e-books like a library

last_post.content:
When you think about public libraries and the publishers’ market power in digital book licensing, sit for a minute with the fact that publishers view free book lending as a form of unfair competition that they’d like to eliminate. If ©️ law can’t support and sustain public libraries in the digital age, then its constitutional purpose has been abandoned. #copyright #lawfedi

The Internet Archive has lost its first fight to scan and lend e-books like a library - The Verge https://www.theverge.com/2023/3/24/23655804/internet-archive-hatchette-publisher-ebook-library-lawsuit

title: Meadows, other top Trump aides ordered to testify in Jan. 6 probe as judge rejects claims of executive privilege

last_post.content:
Oh goodness.

Now we know what that mystery docket entry was:

Looks like a federal judge rejected Trump's claims of executive privilege and has ordered Mark Meadows and other former top aides to testify before a federal grand jury investigating Trump's efforts to overturn the election leading up to the Jan. 6 attack.

This is separate from the Corcoran matter, which pertained to the classified docs.

https://abcnews.go.com/US/meadows-top-trump-aides-ordered-testify-jan-6/story?id=98101813

title: AI Is Ushering in a Textpocalypse

last_post.content:
“What if, in the end, we are done in not by missiles or climate change, not by microscopic pathogens or a mountain-size meteor, but by … text? Simple, plain, unadorned text, but in quantities so immense as to be all but unimaginable—a tsunami of text swept into a self-perpetuating cataract of content that makes it functionally impossible to reliably communicate in any digital setting?”
https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2023/03/ai-chatgpt-writing-language-models/673318/

title: ChatGPT can’t access the internet, even though it really looks like it can

last_post.content: You do have to maintain a very critical eye at all times - it's so easy to develop an incorrect mental model, like thinking ChatGPT can retrieve and read a URL because it generates a very convincing looking (though actually purely hallucinated) summary when you paste one in https://simonwillison.net/2023/Mar/10/chatgpt-internet-access/

title: Web fingerprinting is worse than I thought - Bitestring's Blog

last_post.content:
This is a great article on #privacy and #browser #fingerprinting - including how to block it in browsers like @mozilla #Firefox.

I was really surprised that this was not a default setting in Firefox.

title: Really Sans Case Study

last_post.content:
I recommend reading this case study if you are interested in any of the following things:

• Animated Bézier curves.
• 1970s typography.
• Pantograph engraving machines.
• Photographically modifying letters with lenses.
• Fonts designed to work at specific point sizes.
• The typography of the advertising headline.
• A flexible new sans serif typeface designed for contemporary use.

https://lettermatic.com/custom/really-sans

#design #typography #font #casestudy #history #research

title: schopie1 (@schopie1@hcommons.social)

last_post.content:
My colleague @schopie1 and I have been talking for some time about what might be possible if academic annual review processes were seen as formative (what will make it possible for you do great work in the years ahead) rather than summative (did you do enough this year). He's actively working on a framework for Formative Annual Review (FAR), and I am super excited about where it might lead us.

Edited to add the link I forgot to include: https://hcommons.social/@schopie1/110080183575265341

title: Twitter blocked 122 accounts in India at the government’s request

last_post.content:
via @restofworld:

“Twitter blocked 122 accounts belonging to journalists, authors, and politicians in India this week in response to multiple legal requests from the Indian government.”

Stunningly, the list of the banned includes Canadian poet Rupi Kaur, best known for emo poems on loneliness and identity written in all lowercase. I'm a little dumbfounded.

#India #TwitterBlocks #RupiKaur

https://restofworld.org/2023/twitter-blocked-access-punjab-amritpal-singh-sandhu/

title: Elon Musk Today

last_post.content: It wasn't until digging into Musk background after the whole going after the guy who criticized his cave rescue submarine stunt that I realized how many times he just made shit up as on the verge of existing or 1-2 years away tops to have it be total BS. Good news, now there is a site that tracks it. It is truly mind bending that people take what he says at face value any longer. He is more grifter and charlatan than "real world Tony Stark" tech genius. The data is all there for you to see for yourself. #ElonMusk #MuskIsADick elonmusk.today/

title: scrapeghost

last_post.content:
So for the past couple of weeks, I've been playing with using GPT to transform HTML to JSON, basically enabling one-shot web scrapers.

Like a lot of things with these models, it went from "oh that's interesting" to "wait, it can do that?" really quickly.

I've now turned my experiments into a full-fledged library: https://jamesturk.github.io/scrapeghost/

If you're interested, definitely read through the tutorial, I tried to recapture some of the "wow" discoveries: https://jamesturk.github.io/scrapeghost/tutorial/

title: blog.archive.org/2023/03/25/th...

last_post.content:
It strictly adheres to the *new* precedent that *politics* will (someday) force upon the law.

We see this in play with the copyright case against the @internetarchive, which a lower court badly fumbled yesterday, ruling against the right of libraries to scan their print holdings and lend them out because there is a "licensed" ebooks from publishers - ebooks that cost many multiples of the print editions and self-destruct after just a few lend-outs:

https://blog.archive.org/2023/03/25/the-fight-continues/

28/

title: Pluralistic: The Golden Rule (them what has the gold makes the rules) (25 Mar 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
For many #ConstitutionalLaw scholars, last years' #Dobbs decision on #AbortionRights at the #SupremeCourt came as a dismaying shock, because it showed conclusively that #conlaw wasn't a realm of ideologically consistent intellectual foment, but rather, a matter of *politics*.

--

If you'd like an essay-formatted version of this thread to read or share, here's a link to it on pluralistic.net, my surveillance-free, ad-free, tracker-free blog:

https://pluralistic.net/2023/03/25/consequentialism/#dotards-in-robes

title: MU puzzle - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
People talk about #ChatGPT or #Bing or #Bard or other #LLM passing bar exams or the USMLE Step exams or whatever, but my current benchmark for "reasoning" is Hofstadter's MU puzzle.¹ I change the symbols from 'M', 'I', and 'U', to 'A', 'B', and 'C' just to spice it up. So far they all still fail. They start off solid, but then begin violating rules and declaring erroneous victory. Anyway, it's a fun challenge and a way to still feel superior to the machine.

¹ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MU_puzzle

title: A privacy-first, open-source knowledge base

last_post.content: @cadey For those preferring digital over physical: personal knowledge bases like https://logseq.com or https://obsidian.md work in a similar fashion, but topics can be tagged and linked, and everything is searchable. They are basically a bunch of markdown files pretending to be a fancy knowledge graph. And they do so really well. #logseq #obsidianmd

last_post.content:
Hallo #Mastodon,

@NoraReed haben ihren Weg ins #Fediverse gefunden und ihre ikonischen Bots auf #Twitter abgeschaltet. Auch endloses Schreien und Bienenattacken konnten wohl den Ungeist dort nicht vertreiben. Doch zum Glück fanden @scream 😱 und @bees 🐝 ebenso hier ihre neue Heimat!

Nice to see {macrtools} package from @coatless

An R package that sets up the R compilation toolchain on macOS (Arm and Intel)

I was having a devil of a time compiling R from scratch. And even when compiled I managed to get a segfault :(

This looks like a great timesaver!

https://mac.thecoatlessprofessor.com/macrtools/

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fckF0fefXQ

#RStats

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.13966.pdf

last_post.content:
"The very terms used by the researchers who named these benchmark assessments—“general language understanding,” “natural language inference,” “reading comprehension,” “commonsense reasoning,” and so on—reveal an assumption that humanlike understanding is required to perform well on these tasks. But do these tasks actually require such understanding? Not necessarily." - @melaniemitchell, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.13966.pdf

/cc @matthew, @vaurora

title: The script I use to set up a new mac just the way I like it

last_post.content:
Every time I set up a new mac, I update my install script that gets things most of the way installed for me.

Here's the newest version, in case it's helpful to anybody: https://gist.github.com/llimllib/c4dd0a98a426022b0365d4c0a9090460

- ask you for your new computer's name and set it
- set a bunch of preferences
- install homebrew and a base set of packages, both CLI and apps
- install programming language environments with `asdf`

The script's been in (very intermittent) development for 7 years now!

Reminder that voting in the 2022 #DHAwards closes this weekend (March 26)

My website "What is #DigitalHumanities? The Album" is a nominee in the DH for fun category.

If you like your DH set to popular music but still well footnoted  and encoded in TEI, then check it out (and maybe vote for it!)

As with all DH projects, it's a work in progress; the next song 'Epistolary' (networks) is almost ready for release!

https://what-is-dh-the-album.netlify.app/​

http://dhawards.org/dhawards2022/voting/​

title: https://firstdonoharm.dev

last_post.content:
#TodayILearned about the Hippocratic License 3.0 (HL3): An Ethical License for Open Source Communities, which "aims to confront the potential harms and abuses technology can have on fundamental human rights. It empowers open source communities to establish a clear set of ethical standards that licensees must abide by in order to adopt their code."¹ There's a builder tool² that allows you to customize the license with specific areas of concern.

¹ https://firstdonoharm.dev
² https://firstdonoharm.dev/build/

last_post.content:

title: scrapeghost

last_post.content:
So for the past couple of weeks, I've been playing with using GPT to transform HTML to JSON, basically enabling one-shot web scrapers.

Like a lot of things with these models, it went from "oh that's interesting" to "wait, it can do that?" really quickly.

I've now turned my experiments into a full-fledged library: https://jamesturk.github.io/scrapeghost/

If you're interested, definitely read through the tutorial, I tried to recapture some of the "wow" discoveries: https://jamesturk.github.io/scrapeghost/tutorial/

title: Blog | Quantity is for Production, Quality is for Performance

last_post.content:
Hey! Check out this piece I wrote with @grimalkina! We did a deep lit review across the management and social sciences to talk about wtf #productivity ACTUALLY means, how it’s conflated with things like #production and #performance and how we need to move past looking for a single metric and instead think about #developers holistically and in the context of systems. #softwareengineering

https://www.pluralsight.com/blog/learning-and-development/what-productivity-really-means-in-software-engineering?utm_source=linkedin&utm_medium=organic-social&utm_campaign=developer-experience&utm_term=global&utm_content=blog-what-productivity-really-means-in-software-engineering&exp=3

title: Florida textbook removed Rosa Parks' race to comply with state rules: NYT

last_post.content:
Florida teacher: Rosa Parks was ordered to sit in the back of the bus.

Student: Why?

Teacher: We're not allowed to tell you. But that act of defiance led to a movement for equal rights.

Student: Rights for whom?

Teacher: We're not allowed to tell you.

#RosaParks #Florida #DeSantis #TrueHistory #history #Education
--------
A publisher removed references to Rosa Parks' race in a draft of its textbook to comply with Florida's laws, NYT reports
https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-textbook-removed-rosa-parks-race-comply-state-desantis-rules-2023-3

title: Three myths about Hopkins Street - Marc Hedlund - Medium

last_post.content:
I … cannot even believe this.

Chris Lee-Egan and I wrote a Medium piece (https://medium.com/@marcprecipice/three-myths-about-hopkins-street-c09712029084) about misinformation in the #Hopkins bike lane debates. We quoted opponents of the lanes talking about severe injuries and deaths on the street.

They have a response up claiming “no one ever said” what we claimed. But … they still say it, on the same site where they published their rebuttal. 🤯🤯🤯

(The rest of the rebuttal is ridiculous, too.) #BikeTooter #RoadSafety #Berkeley
